ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend the course to anyone with an interest in the Francophone Caribbean or postcolonial theory. Again, though, I wish we could have covered a broader range of topics and authors.

Fren 935 is a survey of AimÃ© CÃ©saire's major works with a focus on his Cahier. I would not recommend it to someone who would be looking for a broader introduction to Francophone or Antillean literature, nor to someone who would be interested mainly in CÃ©saire's poetry.

The course surveys Aime Cesaire's work as an author and politician and the political and critical reactions to his work. I would recommend the course to another student, as it gives good perspective on a significant figure in francophone literature and the politics of decolonization.

I would highly recommend this course to another student. French 935 delves into the life and work of the important Caribbean figure, AimÃ© CÃ©saire. Professor Miller creates a lively classroom environment that greatly enhances the readings, which he selects with great care.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It introduced me to an area of study that I may want to pursue in the future, which is to say the Francophone Caribbean. Even if I can only really claim familiarity with one of its authors, that alone is a useful start.

The course gave me a better understanding of the interaction between the politics of decolonization and assimilation and the birth of francophone literature as we know it. I consider this essential base knowledge for anyone studying French literature.
